title: Helping Humans
heroTitle: How to help your customers keep their data safe

heroDescription.heroDescription:
While this Identity and Security Meetup is an online event to replace the physical ones in Melbourne and Sydney, it is naturally open to anyone around the world.

Please join the session 5 or 10 minutes prior to the start time to give yourself time to remedy any issues before we begin.

We value diversity and operate a strict code of conduct, for the comfort of all our members. Please see [our code of conduct](https://auth0.com/events/code-of-conduct).

childMarkdownRemark.rawMarkdownBody:
While this Identity and Security Meetup is an online event to replace the physical ones in Melbourne and Sydney, it is naturally open to anyone around the world.

Please join the session 5 or 10 minutes prior to the start time to give yourself time to remedy any issues before we begin.

We value diversity and operate a strict code of conduct, for the comfort of all our members. Please see [our code of conduct](https://auth0.com/events/code-of-conduct).

Each year, through Stay Smart Online Week, the Australian Government works with governments, industry, small business operators and community groups to raise awareness about the ways people can protect themselves online.

The national awareness week is held in October each year and focuses on a key theme that highlights an important safety message.

Due to logistical issues, this event takes place the week following Stay Smart Online Week.

topicsSubsections.title: Helping the Humans: How to help your customers keep their data safe

description.description:
Computers are terrible because they're built by humans, and humans make mistakes. Your customers are also humans, and they will make mistakes, so how can you design a system that helps them instead of one that hurts them?

Learn how to avoid dark patterns that place customer data at risk, how to avoid common ways to fail, and how to be a better system designer. Get tips on designing systems that are secure and private by design, and how to know your system is putting humans in danger before you end up on the front page of the newspaper.

intro.intro: He has been published in Forbes.com, iTNews.com.au, CRN Australia, and The Saturday Paper. He is a board member of Electronic Frontiers Australia and is frequently quoted in the media on issues dealing with data security, privacy, and government use of IT. He enjoys coding in Python and R, summarising boring documents on Twitter, and filing FOI requests.
